articles.headline: Drone Strikes Are Said to Kill Taliban Chief
articles.snippet: The killing deals a major blow to a group that has terrorized Pakistan and tried to set off a car bomb in New York in 2010, according to Pakistani intelligence officials and militant commanders.
articles.abstract: The killing deals a major blow to a group that has terrorized Pakistan and tried to set off a car bomb in New York in 2010, according to Pakistani intelligence officials and militant commanders.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — American drones on Friday killed the leader of the Pakistani Taliban, dealing a major blow to a militant group that has terrorized Pakistan and that tried to set off a car bomb in New York City in 2010, according to Pakistani intelligence officials and militant commanders in the tribal belt.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh, Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud and Ismail Khan

articles.headline: High Income, Low Taxes and Never a Bad Year
articles.snippet: Even in 2009, when the global economy hit the wall, the richest Americans were able to cash in thanks to regressively low rates on capital gains.
articles.abstract: Even in 2009, when the global economy hit the wall, the richest Americans were able to cash in thanks to regressively low rates on capital gains.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the superrich, 2009 was supposed to be the “annus horribilis.”

articles.headline: F.C.C. Plans Sweeping Changes to Bolster AM Radio
articles.snippet: The Federal Communications Commission has proposed loosening or eliminating rules that govern nighttime transmissions by AM stations.
articles.abstract: The Federal Communications Commission has proposed loosening or eliminating rules that govern nighttime transmissions by AM stations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission, seeking to revive the sagging fortunes of AM radio, has proposed removing or updating regulations that station owners believe have left many AM channels on the precipice of death.

articles.headline: U.S. Broadens Investigation of JPMorgan’s Hiring in Asia
articles.snippet: A filing indicates that federal authorities are looking into the bank’s “business relationships with certain related clients in the Asia Pacific region and its engagement of consultants in the Asia Pacific region.”
articles.abstract: A filing indicates that federal authorities are looking into the bank’s “business relationships with certain related clients in the Asia Pacific region and its engagement of consultants in the Asia Pacific region.”
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal investigation into the hiring practices of JPMorgan Chase has expanded beyond the borders of China, where the bank faces questions about whether it hired the children of powerful Chinese officials to win lucrative business there.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: This Little LED of Mine
articles.snippet: The common complaint about compact fluorescent lights, the harsh glow, may have an energy-efficient answer, especially as LED bulbs fall under $10 each.
articles.abstract: The common complaint about compact fluorescent lights, the harsh glow, may have an energy-efficient answer, especially as LED bulbs fall under $10 each.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nancy Finkelmeier tried to make the switch more than a year ago. After hearing that the long life of compact fluorescent bulbs would help her avoid changing the lights in her 15-foot ceilings so often, she got rid of her traditional incandescent bulbs in favor of the new ones.

articles.headline: 2 Democrats Split on Tactics to Fight Military Sex Assaults
articles.snippet: As Senators Kirsten Gillibrand and Claire McCaskill mount fierce separate campaigns, the conflict has created an uncomfortable division between the Senate’s women.
articles.abstract: As Senators Kirsten Gillibrand and Claire McCaskill mount fierce separate campaigns, the conflict has created an uncomfortable division between the Senate’s women.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A sweeping Pentagon policy bill that would make significant changes to how the military deals with sexual assault has turned into a battle between two powerful and determined Democrats who have offered competing proposals.

articles.headline: Republican Rivalry Simmers as Paths and Styles Diverge
articles.snippet: The strategies pursued by Ted Cruz and Rand Paul could help determine whether the Tea Party remains at war with the G.O.P. establishment or is eventually integrated.
articles.abstract: The strategies pursued by Ted Cruz and Rand Paul could help determine whether the Tea Party remains at war with the G.O.P. establishment or is eventually integrated.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Senator Ted Cruz calls his colleague Rand Paul a “good friend.” The two men are the stars of the Tea Party movement, propelled to Washington by activist fervor and allied in their effort to restrain the reach of the federal government.

articles.headline: Twitter Helps Revive a Seedy San Francisco Neighborhood
articles.snippet: Before Twitter moved in, San Francisco’s Mid-Market area was run down and not very safe. Now that’s changed, thanks to tax breaks and a need for office space in the city.
articles.abstract: Before Twitter moved in, San Francisco’s Mid-Market area was run down and not very safe. Now that’s changed, thanks to tax breaks and a need for office space in the city.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The middle stretch of Market Street here has befuddled mayors, investors and entrepreneurs for decades.

articles.headline: Russian Service, and With Please and Thank You
articles.snippet: Russian companies are carrying out elaborate training that is producing a new generation of service employees who are customer-oriented.
articles.abstract: Russian companies are carrying out elaborate training that is producing a new generation of service employees who are customer-oriented.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The classroom filled with slender young men and women in their first week of training at the Aeroflot academy for flight attendants. The men were all square-jawed and broad-shouldered, and the women to the last of them traffic-stopping beauties.

articles.headline: Seeking to Toughen the Rules for Brokers
articles.snippet: It is too easy for stock and insurance brokers to avoid rules that would require them to put their customers first when picking their investments for their individual retirement accounts.
articles.abstract: It is too easy for stock and insurance brokers to avoid rules that would require them to put their customers first when picking their investments for their individual retirement accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: When you seek advice from a professional about where to invest your retirement savings, you hope the advice giver is acting in your best interest — not profiting at your expense.

articles.headline: No Morsel Too Minuscule for All-Consuming N.S.A.
articles.snippet: The National Security Agency finds itself under intense pressure after disclosures of spying on allies and rivals alike, but it defends the wide net it casts.
articles.abstract: The National Security Agency finds itself under intense pressure after disclosures of spying on allies and rivals alike, but it defends the wide net it casts.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, sat down with President Obama at the White House in April to discuss Syrian chemical weapons, Israeli-Palestinian peace talks and climate change, it was a cordial, routine exchange.

articles.headline: At Los Angeles International Airport, Two Lives Collide in a Fatal Instant
articles.snippet: As officials sought a motive for Paul A. Ciancia, charged in the death of a T.S.A. agent, it became clear that he was a drifter with a grudge against the government.
articles.abstract: As officials sought a motive for Paul A. Ciancia, charged in the death of a T.S.A. agent, it became clear that he was a drifter with a grudge against the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One was a troubled 23-year-old, with an assault rifle and an apparent grudge against the government, who witnesses said seemed to be hunting for airport security officials. The other was a 39-year-old father of two who for three years had been a screener of the torrent of passengers who move through the security lines at Los Angeles International Airport.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina and Ian Lovett

articles.headline: At Sears, Those Big Losses Get in the Way
articles.snippet: Eight years into a merger, a retailer’s transformation is still a work in progress. Could a spin-off of a prized asset, Lands’ End, help?
articles.abstract: Eight years into a merger, a retailer’s transformation is still a work in progress. Could a spin-off of a prized asset, Lands’ End, help?
articles.lead_paragraph: “I’d like to go faster. I’d like to go bigger. We’re just not making money, which makes it much, much harder to fund the transformation.”

articles.headline: Riding the Hashtag in Social Media Marketing
articles.snippet: Gary Vaynerchuk, a social media marketer, pounces on any trend — tweeted or otherwise — in his quest to sell, sell, sell.
articles.abstract: Gary Vaynerchuk, a social media marketer, pounces on any trend — tweeted or otherwise — in his quest to sell, sell, sell.
articles.lead_paragraph: About once a week, Gary Vaynerchuk posts a Twitter message that reads, “Is there anything I can do for you?” He means it literally. He is inviting his roughly one million followers to send requests for any kind of help or favor. And if you respond, he will try to punch you in the face.

articles.headline: I.O.U.’s Give the Democrat an Edge in Virginia
articles.snippet: Democrats nationwide are reaching out to Terry McAuliffe, a former fund-raiser, with endorsements, strategic advice and, of course, an avalanche of money for his run for governor.
articles.abstract: Democrats nationwide are reaching out to Terry McAuliffe, a former fund-raiser, with endorsements, strategic advice and, of course, an avalanche of money for his run for governor.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Their cheeks brushed as they whispered into each other’s ears, Bill Clinton and Terry McAuliffe, together again.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: That Other Big Afghan Crisis, the Growing Army of Addicts
articles.snippet: A new report underscores a growing crisis in the city of Herat: one in every five households contains at least one drug user.
articles.abstract: A new report underscores a growing crisis in the city of Herat: one in every five households contains at least one drug user.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAM QALA, Afghanistan — The addicts stalk the streets of this border post like hollowed-out skeletons, hair matted by filth and eyes glassy. The villages that hug the roads are veritable zombie towns, where families of men, women and children hide their addiction within barren mud compounds.

articles.headline: Seeking More Pay for Delayed Play
articles.snippet: With the pace of delayed television viewing increasing, networks want advertisers to pay for seven days of commercial viewing to cover computer screens and tablets as well as TV sets.
articles.abstract: With the pace of delayed television viewing increasing, networks want advertisers to pay for seven days of commercial viewing to cover computer screens and tablets as well as TV sets.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2007, faced with the growing popularity of digital video recorders, advertisers agreed to pay television networks for commercials viewed within three days of a show’s first broadcast.

articles.headline: Ads Scant When Twitter Crosses Borders
articles.snippet: Though three-quarters of its users are outside the United States, only a modest portion of its ad revenue is generated there. But it’s growing fast.
articles.abstract: Though three-quarters of its users are outside the United States, only a modest portion of its ad revenue is generated there. But it’s growing fast.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — From Manila to Madrid, international consumers now represent more than three-quarters of the 232 million people who regularly use Twitter.

articles.headline: Stratospheric Views, and Prices
articles.snippet: Hard as it may be to believe, the price per square foot for luxury apartments in New York City is considerably less than it is for luxury elsewhere in the world.
articles.abstract: Hard as it may be to believe, the price per square foot for luxury apartments in New York City is considerably less than it is for luxury elsewhere in the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: Walking slowly to the windows facing the meadow of green that is Central Park, Gary Barnett slips into salesman mode as he spreads his arms wide, embracing the sweeping bird’s-eye view he has from the 87th floor of his shimmering skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan.

articles.headline: Under Health Care Act, Millions Eligible for Free Policies
articles.snippet: Federal subsidies will pay the entire monthly cost of some plans being offered in the online marketplaces, a surprising figure that has not gotten much attention, in part because the zero-premium plans come with serious trade-offs.
articles.abstract: Federal subsidies will pay the entire monthly cost of some plans being offered in the online marketplaces, a surprising figure that has not gotten much attention, in part because the zero-premium plans come with serious trade-offs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of people could qualify for federal subsidies that will pay the entire monthly cost of some health care plans being offered in the online marketplaces set up under President Obama’s health care law, a surprising figure that has not garnered much attention, in part because the zero-premium plans come with serious trade-offs.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: To Shape Young Palestinians, Hamas Creates Its Own Textbooks
articles.snippet: The Hamas movement is deviating from the approved Palestinian Authority curriculum, using the new texts as part of a broader push to infuse the next generation with its militant ideology.
articles.abstract: The Hamas movement is deviating from the approved Palestinian Authority curriculum, using the new texts as part of a broader push to infuse the next generation with its militant ideology.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — When a class of Palestinian ninth graders in Gaza recently discussed the deadly 1929 riots over access to the Western Wall in Jerusalem, it was guided by a new textbook, introduced this fall by the Islamist Hamas movement.
articles.byline: By Fares Akram and Jodi Rudoren

articles.headline: SAC Nears an Insider Trading Guilty Plea, but Legal Cases Aren’t Shut
articles.snippet: A plea deal for SAC Capital Advisors would resolve a criminal case involving insider trading charges, but the firm’s owner, Steven A. Cohen, would still face a civil lawsuit.
articles.abstract: A plea deal for SAC Capital Advisors would resolve a criminal case involving insider trading charges, but the firm’s owner, Steven A. Cohen, would still face a civil lawsuit.
articles.lead_paragraph: The criminal case against the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors has reached a conclusion, people briefed on the matter said, with the government expected to announce Monday that SAC will plead guilty to insider trading charges and pay a fine of roughly $1.2 billion.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: Koch Group Has Ambitions in Small Races
articles.snippet: Backed by the billionaire Koch brothers, Americans for Prosperity has campaigned against taxes and spending in Coralville, Iowa, but some voters are skeptical of its motives.
articles.abstract: Backed by the billionaire Koch brothers, Americans for Prosperity has campaigned against taxes and spending in Coralville, Iowa, but some voters are skeptical of its motives.
articles.lead_paragraph: CORALVILLE, Iowa — Election seasons in this small eastern Iowa town are usually cordial affairs. But this year, a group backed by the billionaire Koch brothers has changed that.

articles.headline: With ‘Alpha House,’ Amazon Makes Bid for Living Room Screens and Beyond
articles.snippet: The show, Amazon’s first attempt at original programming, could create additional momentum for change in the concept of television.
articles.abstract: The show, Amazon’s first attempt at original programming, could create additional momentum for change in the concept of television.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I was on the set of a show about politics, Washington and a senator gone rogue. The set had all the trappings of a big-time television production, but it will be delivered not by broadcast or cable, but over the Internet by a technology company that has not historically been in the business of original productions.

articles.headline: Egypt’s Ex-President Is Defiant at Murder Trial
articles.snippet: The trial, on charges of inciting the murder of protesters, was Mohamed Morsi’s first public appearance since his removal from office in July. It was adjourned for two months.
articles.abstract: The trial, on charges of inciting the murder of protesters, was Mohamed Morsi’s first public appearance since his removal from office in July. It was adjourned for two months.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Held incommunicado for the four months since his overthrow as president, Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood walked into a makeshift courtroom on Monday for his new role as a defendant in a murder trial.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Mayy El Sheikh

articles.headline: A Takeover Bid for BlackBerry Collapses, and Its Chief Executive Vacates His Post
articles.snippet: The troubled smartphone maker will instead receive a $1 billion investment from institutional investors, including Fairfax Financial, its largest shareholder. John S. Chen, a former chief executive of Sybase, will be interim chief executive.
articles.abstract: The troubled smartphone maker will instead receive a $1 billion investment from institutional investors, including Fairfax Financial, its largest shareholder. John S. Chen, a former chief executive of Sybase, will be interim chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:06 p.m. | OTTAWA — A tentative takeover bid for BlackBerry from its largest shareholder collapsed on Monday, clouding the immediate future of the company.
articles.byline: By Ian Austen and David Gelles
